name: Jinteki Matchpoint Run
description:
Target deck when HnP comes out. The object of the game is to get to match point as soon as possible. This would threaten the runner to run almost anything you install and advance. Allowing you to play the June bugs and the Overwritters with more efficiency.

I'm thinking one doesn't need big Ice as games should be short and done before the runner can set up his rig.

What do you guys think?

name: Den Bosch, The Netherlands, Store Championship First place
description:
A small group of 7 played a championship in Holland yesterday. This deck got me the win, going undefeated, 4-0. No Fear and Loathing.

Deck was designed by Stimhack/BBG-er Lysander.

name: Den Bosch, The Netherlands, Store Championship First place
description:
A small group of 7 played a championship in Holland yesterday. I went 2-2 with the deck. I made some mistakes, and was unlucky one time. Probably will look for another Criminal deck.

All credits to Team Covenant's Timm Bunn for the decklist. I just butchered it ;)

name: Gabriel, The Ambush Begins V1.0
GRNDL, Killing the Odds V1.2
HB: CI - MoMoney!!
description: I took this deck to my Store Championship recently and its did pretty well.

name: NBN Fast Advance 1.0
Kit ICE destruction v3
description: minor tweaks to previous decks.

name: The NEXT Wall V1.1
description:
Built this deck for a tournament last weekend. Despite looking really simple, it was actually great fun! This deck only does 3 things: Score agenda's, make money and build a huge wall in the meantime. During the whole five rounds I've hardly had any money problems. Especially after a few celebrity gifts and successful demonstrations. The large amounts of reasonably cheap ice makes rezzing lots of ice early game not really an issue. For me the sweet spot was 3 layers of ice on HQ, R&D and 1 remote. Less ice on another remote and archives. Usually this is all set up pretty fast. After that it's a race against the clock.

This deck is strong early and mid game. This is because essentially you've got a free turn and with 21 pieces of ice it's not hard to get at least 2 ice in your starting hand. Usually I had at least 2 (less than 2 means a mulligen). Once the mid game passes the runner gets a really big upperhand and all the ice isn't too hard to get through. This isn't fast advance, but with 5x 3/2 agendas it doesn't go slow either.

EDIT: I took absolutely no tracer or bad pub ice because it has no place in this deck. Money is for rezzing my ice and scoring agendas (except Ichi, but he is there for trashing programs). Bad pub means the runner can go through my cheaper ice for free. Archived Mem and Vitruvius is used for Celeb gift and SanSan.

Notes:

-Heimdall I still find really iffy. It looks all impressive, but really isn't hard to get through. I do still need at least a few late game ICE to make it harder for the runner later on.

  • I'm going to replace Enigma with Quandry once it's out.

  • I'm convinced that once more NEXT ice comes out, this deck will really start rolling.

  • I've only played 8 times with this deck. There is probably loads of improvement options, but up till now it has worked really well for me.

  • It was fun playing something hardly any of my opponents have ever played against.

name: NBN - basic tag deck
description: Not sure if some of the outside cards are necessary, but Director Haas seems like a nice addition so I can place, score, and run a Closed Accounts or Scorched Earth inside one turn.

name: Professional Thief v5.1
Ser Santiago v1.0
Wy H.Tag v2
LLDS Kate
Jintekill
Can't Catch The Red Queen
description:
In contrast to the tag-me archetype, I thought it'd be fun to run a never tag deck. At a full rig, we're getting 3 passive credits a turn, 5 recurring icebreaker credits, a link strength of 9, a hand size of 8 and 8 memory.

More likely, we're looking at an easy time with traces as even a modest rig can hit 4 link with good, passive econ. Crypsis/Parasite/Datasucker help us with large ice. Kati/Underworld keep us rolling in deep credits while recurring credits soften up servers for us. Darwin is nice early against small ice (ice walls/rotos/etc) to keep us in servers, but may be worth switch out for something.

name: Russian Jackson 1.3 GP Store Championship Top 4
description: Try to start with a Biotic or SanSan City Grid. Get 5-8 bucks. Score agendas. Use Jackson to rush them to your hand, while Grim to destroy those Fracters that get through your barriers. You will usually win quick or lose quick.

name: Good Ol' Gabe 1.6 GP Store Championship Top 4
description: I've been playing a version of this since I bought into this game about a year ago. It really hasn't let me down. Your starting hand really wants to see Hostage, Desperado, perhaps some Hedge Funds, and maybe a Special Order. Run like crazy. Hit ice head on until you absolutely have to play breakers. With new program trashing out there, be careful not to lose both your Corroders or Key Masters. R&DI gets you the pressure you need there. Blackmail can be huge against Weyland, but does well against all the Grim and Fenris floating around.

name: Gabriel, The Ambush Begins V1.4
Seattle Phoenix Comics and Games 3/8/2014 SC 1st place corp
description:
This deck pseudo-won one of the Seattle SCs (14 entrants) yesterday. I only say pseudo because I would have had to play Andrew Veen (2nd at worlds) in the finals but he conceded to give more players first round byes at regionals since he already had one. He beat me proper in Swiss rounds, but at least one of the games felt close to me (my corp game I was one turn away from winning).

Anyway, it's a Making News Midseason deck. It's based off of Jesse Vandover's semifinalist Worlds deck, but updated for Fear and Loathing. A lot of the tools that he was using in there NBN can now get influence free, so I used the extra influence on a bunch of Celebrity Gifts for even more burst economy. The goal is to tax the runner with expensive to break ice and make it hard to run servers repeatedly.

name: Seattle Phoenix Comics and Games 3/8/2014 SC 1st place runnr
description:
This deck pseudo-won one of the Seattle SCs (14 entrants) yesterday. I only say pseudo because I would have had to play Andrew Veen (2nd at worlds) in the finals but he conceded to give more players first round byes at regionals since he already had one. He beat me proper in Swiss rounds, but at least one of the games felt close to me (my corp game I was one turn away from winning).

Anyway, it's a fairly standard Professional Anarch deck. There's one copy of each of the anarch core breakers, datasuckers and tools to still get you into servers before you can get the full suite out. Nothing that stands out too much otherwise.

name: Untrashable Reversion
description: In honor to the great db0!

name: Parasite Kate
description: This deck I took to my Store Championship recently

name: When Bioroids Attack (Oslo Store Championship)
Andy in the Red Dress (Oslo Store Championship)
Castelldefells Mod
description:
I copied this deck from one that won at Castelldefells Store Championship (http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/2364/first-place-castelldefells-store-championship). I added the link so he/she gets all the credit for this deck. My changes were minor, but worked great for me. I played this deck in a store championship today (http://www.atomicgoblingames.com/ in Longmont Colorado.) and it did really well. I had to leave early due to life commitments, but I think if I had stayed this deck would have rocked.

This is my first Kit deck and I like that it isn't a yog deck, which everyone expects. I thought this deck was light without a console, but it doesn't need one. This rig uses cheap chips to boost memory when needed. Below are the changes I made.

-Blackmail to deal with all the Bad Publicity. Makes the corp think twice about getting so much bad pub. -Same old Thing allows me to pull Blackmail or another event, multiple times. -Removed Professional Contacts, they are too expensive. Katie Jones brings in enough economy for what I need.

I thought this deck was light without a console, but it doesn't need one. This rig uses cheap chips to boost memory when needed.

name: 2014 Haunted Store Championship - 1st Place Corp
description:
March 8th, 2014 - Tobin L's corporation deck from The Haunted Game Cafe's Store Championship.

After four rounds of Swiss, Tobin went 3-1 with this deck and finished in first place.

name: 2014 Haunted Store Championship - 1st Place Runner
description:
March 8th, 2014 - Tobin L's runner deck from The Haunted Game Cafe's Store Championship.

After four rounds of Swiss, Tobin went 3-1 with this deck and finished in first place.
